key_points: The 1903 film 'The Great Train Robbery' marked the start of Hollywood's long-standing relationship with guns.
The accidental shooting on the set of 'Rust' by Alec Baldwin, resulting in the death of cinematographer Halyna Hutchins, has sparked a debate on gun use in film production.
Many in the industry, including 'Black Panther' cinematographer Rachel Morrison, advocate for the elimination of live fire on sets, citing technological alternatives.
Following the 'Rust' tragedy, some productions have started relying on airsoft guns and CGI to simulate gunfire, prioritizing safety and cost.
ABC's 'The Rookie' decided to eliminate the use of live weapons on set, focusing on the importance of cast and crew safety.
California State Senator Dave Cortese announced plans to introduce legislation banning live ammunition and firearms on movie and theatrical production sets.
The International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees (IATSE) is pushing for improved safety measures amid contract negotiations with studios.
Some argue that while eliminating live ammunition is crucial, guns capable of firing only blanks should not be completely banned if safety protocols are observed.
Critics of banning real guns from sets include a group of armorers and weapons masters who emphasize competence and following established safety procedures.
Advocates for CG gun effects argue that it not only enhances safety but also meets contemporary expectations of realism in filmmaking.
spokespersons: Gary Truers (Armorer and Weapons Master, 'Jurassic World')
